cmCourseInfo.description: Failures of classical physics; the Quantum revolution; Stern-Gerlach effect; harmonic oscillator; uncertainty principle; interference packets; scattering and tunneling in one-dimension.

courses.name: Political Theory: Visions of the Just/Good Society

cmCourseInfo.description: A selective presentation of critical encounters between philosophy and politics, dedicated to the quest for articulation and founding of the just/good society. Among the theorists examined are Plato, Aristotle, Machiavelli, Hobbes and Locke.
cmCourseInfo.title: Political Theory: Visions of the Just/Good Society

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online synchronous course.  Lectures and tutorials will be delivered synchronously (i.e., you will attend and participate in live-streaming lectures and tutorials). Students need to use Bb Collaborate on Quercus.

courses.name: Politics of Development: Issues and Controversies

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the developmental challenges facing societies in Latin America, the Caribbean, Asia and Africa, and the efficacy of various development strategies and policies in meeting these challenges.
cmCourseInfo.title: Politics of Development: Issues and Controversies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course. Students will receive 3 – 4 hours of online lectures per week asynchronously which will be posted as well.  Students will have the opportunity to participate in optional synchronous online webinars 1-2hrs/) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content, and discuss materials posted by the instructor.  Students need to access Quercus, including Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to U.S. government and politics within an analytical framework that helps us understand how institutions structure incentives and decisions in the U.S. system. This class examines the political forces that forged contemporary American institutions to understand how these political institutions continue to provide stability while allowing opportunities for political change. We investigate whether these forces make American institutions different and why. Special attention is paid to current events and contemporary policy dilemmas.
cmCourseInfo.title: U.S. Government and Politics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course with once-a-week recommended live discussions. Lectures will be given as 3-4 hours online videos/week asynchronously. All lectures feature detailed PowerPoint presentations that can be viewed with video or narration or just read without narration. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class and/or office hours 1.5 hrs/week (Thursdays at 11:00 am to 12:30 pm). Some weeks this webinar will be, at least partially, a weekly lecture, but will also include opportunities to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Additional discussion time in small groups, led by a TA or the instructor, will follow later on Thursday afternoons (time TBA, depending on size of class and student availability). These “live” discussions are recommended, but students who are unable to join the class at that time will be able to use class discussion forums to share their thoughts without penalty for missing the live discussions. Discussions, Q & A office hours, and webinar lectures will take place using Blackboard Collaborate Ultra through Quercus and will be recorded to allow students to review the video afterwards. Students need Power Point (available for free through the university), the ability to download or stream videos of lectures, and access to Quercus to use Blackboard Collaborate and discussion forums. There is a required textbook for this course, which will be available for online purchase through the U of T bookstore and other online vendors (including used copies). The textbook as an ebook can also be purchased or rented for about CAD65. The other required readings for this class are free ebooks or articles available for no cost through the library website.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course analyzes the impact of the individual, the nation-state, and the international and transnational systems on international conflict and conflict resolution, and examines the major problems the international community confronts in a rapidly changing international environment.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to International Relations
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Prior reading or study of modern history

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The course will be an online asynchronous course. Lectures will be delivered as AUDIO recordings with associated Word documents (for text, charts, maps, tables, and similar materials). Office hours will be conducted via e-mail, telephone, or web conference (as needed). Students will have various options to earn their participation grades (e.g., live video conferencing with the TAs, TA-moderated chat rooms, or written submissions). Students will not be required to purchase specialized technology beyond an internet connection and MS Word.

cmCourseInfo.description: Canada's political system including the Constitution and its institutional pillars: cabinet and parliament, federalism, the courts and the Charter of Rights. Topics include political parties, the electoral system, identity and citizenship, ideology and political culture, regionalism, language politics, indigenous peoples, diversity, and media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Government and Politics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course. The lectures will be delivered via Zoom and all reading materials/essay assignments will be posted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces the foundations of quantitative empirical research methods - increasingly popular and important part of political science research and public policy debates - to enable you to interpret and evaluate the results of the studies that employ these methods. Topics include scientific study of politics, empirical research designs, and regression analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Quantitative Reasoning I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course.  Lectures will be given as 3-4 hours online videos/week asynchronously. All lectures feature detailed PowerPoint presentations that can be viewed with video or narration or just read without narration. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class and/or office hours 1.5 hrs/week (Tuesdays at 6 pm to 7:30 pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Many weeks will feature a second online webinar class that will be recorded using Blackboard Collaborate Ultra on Quercus, so students who do not join “live” can listen at their convenience. Students need Power Point (available for free through the university), the ability to download or stream videos of lectures, and access to Quercus to use Blackboard Collaborate and discussion forums. All of the required readings for this class are free ebooks or articles available for no cost through the library website.

cmCourseInfo.description: Building up on POL222H1, students will continue to build theoretical foundations of quantitative empirical research, such as probability theory and statistical inference. They will also learn the basic use of statistical software and have become able to conduct a basic data analysis by themselves by the end of semester.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Quantitative Reasoning II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online asynchronous course with frequent opportunities for live assistance or to watch lectures live. Lectures will be given as 3-4 hours online videos/week asynchronously. All lectures feature detailed PowerPoint presentations that can be viewed with video or narration or just read without narration. Every Tuesday at 6 pm will feature a synchronous online webinar class for 1.5 hrs. This webinar will include some lecture content, time to ask questions and clarifications about lecture, and receive assistance on assignments. Several weeks with statistical assignments will feature a second online webinar class plus online office hours hosted by the instructor and/or the TA that will be recorded using Blackboard Collaborate Ultra on Quercus, so students who do not join “live” can listen at their convenience. These additional sessions will take place on Wednesdays, Thursdays and/or Fridays and the time will be determined after consulting with the class to maximize student availability. While these additional sessions are not required, because some of the work in this course is “hands on” statistical analyses, the timing will be set to maximize availability to ensure many students can work while the instructor or TA is available in real time for assistance. Since this was originally scheduled to be an evening course, at least one session will be offered after 5 pm for students who may be working or have childcare responsibilities during the day. All sessions will be recorded so students who cannot attend live can still benefit from insights and questions posed by other students. Students need Power Point (available for free through the university), Excel, the ability to download or stream videos of lectures, and access to Quercus to use Blackboard Collaborate and discussion forums. The ability to download an open source software program (R or PSPP) will be recommended, but not required. There will be a recommended textbook purchase, but most required readings for this class will be free ebooks or articles available for no cost through the library website.

cmCourseInfo.description: The continuing relevance of pre-colonial Africa; the nature and legacy of colonial rule; African nationalism and the consolidation of power in the newly-independent states; government, party and the people; the role of the military; national integration; dependency and neo-colonialism; socialism and development; democracy and human rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Government and Politics in Africa

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores China’s efforts to construct a modern and effective political order in the face of powerful demographic and revolutionary challenges. The clash between competing ideologies, political and social movements and institutional alternatives in the context of rapid social and economic change are analyzed.
cmCourseInfo.title: State & Society in 20th Century China

Students will be assigned to a synchronous tutorial which will run 50 minutes per week. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra), and to participate in tutorials with a microphone.

cmCourseInfo.description: The foreign policy of the United States: tradition and context of American decision-making, the process by which it is formulated, application to a number of specific regions and problems in the world.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of how political life is being transformed in the global urban age. Concepts such as territory, the state, citizenship, agency, sovereignty, and power will be reconsidered through a particularly urban lens.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online hybrid course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online modules asynchronously. Students will be able to watch these lecture modules on their own time. There will be two lecture modules per week (total of about 6 hours of lecture time per week). Students will have the opportunity for synchronous virtual office hours with the instructor and TAs. Students will also be able to arrange virtual meetings outside of these times. Course assessments will be delivered somewhat synchronously whereby students will have 24 hours to complete tests and/or final assessments. During these types of assessments, the instructor and Tas will be available for questions for some of the hours in the day but availability will not be possible during the entire 24-hour period. Please note that all times for the course will be given in EST (i.e., Toronto time). Students need Word, PDF, Internet, and virtual access to the course textbook and practice questions for this course.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of statistical analysis of experimental and observational data including linear models, the analysis of variance, a priori contrasts, post-hoc tests, power analysis and effect size calculations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics II

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course.
Lectures will be given as 2-hour streams Tuesday and Thursday from 6:00 - 8:00 PM.
Tutorials will be 1 hour and will directly follow the lecture.
Students will access lecture and tutorials through Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: The developmental approach to the study of behaviour with reference to sensorimotor skills, cognition, socialization, personality, and emotional behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Development

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is a hybrid, online course that will be delivered both asynchronously (pre-recorded videos) and synchronously (live webinars).
Weekly asynchronous lecture videos will be available online every Monday.
You will have the opportunity to ask questions and seek clarifications on lectures and course content via weekly synchronous 1-hour tutorials with TAs every Wednesday.
There will also be periodic synchronous sessions with the Course Instructor throughout the term.
Students will be required to use Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra), and Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Contemporary areas of research in social psychology: social perception, attitudes, inter-personal relations, and group processes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Social Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/twice a week asynchronously. The midterms will be synchronous during class time. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar/office hours 2hrs/week (Monday and Thursday 2-3pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: Contemporary areas of research in social psychology: social perception, attitudes, inter-personal relations, and group processes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Social Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/twice a week asynchronously. The midterms will be synchronous during class time. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar/office hours 2hrs/week (Tuesday and Thursday 2-3pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical survey of concepts, theories, and the state of research in the area of psychopathology and therapeutic methods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Abnormal Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures will be given as 2-hour online videos/week asynchronously and discussion will be completed on Quercus.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 3 times per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content.
Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).
Tests will be timed and online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Concepts, theories, and applications of classical and contemporary learning theories, including classical and operant conditioning. Current theories of the physiological and anatomical basis of learning and memory, including synaptic plasticity, the role of the hippocampus, amygdala, frontal cortex and other brain regions. Theories will be related to a practical understanding and applications such as drug addiction, phobias and other disorders.
cmCourseInfo.title: Learning and Plasticity
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online files, 2 times/week, asynchronously.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours Tuesdays (10-11am) and Thursdays (11am-12pm).
Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to research and theory on the neural and cognitive architecture of attention, memory, language, thinking and reasoning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as a series of short videos totaling 2-3 hours/topic (4-6 hours/week) posted on Quercus. Students will have the opportunity for a synchronous online office hour on Wednesdays from 2-3pm via MS Teams to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Discussion boards will also be available to ask questions if students are unable to attend live office hours. Students are expected to complete online homework via Top Hat each week. Students need PowerPoint and Top Hat.

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a solid background into the biological basis of behaviour. Animal and human research topics include functional neuroanatomy, neural signalling, sensory and motor control, motivational systems, and hormones, and emotions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Physiological Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online hybrid course.
Lectures will be given as video recordings (2 – 3 hours) once per week asynchronously.
Virtual office hours sessions (3 hours) will be offered once per week via BB Collaborate (Monday 5 - 8 pm).
Some assessments in the course will be timed and completed on Quercus on specific dates.
Students will need a video player (that can play *.mov), pdf reader and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

notes.content:

cmCourseInfo.description: Age changes in sensory and perceptual processes, motor skill, learning, memory, and personality. Theory, methodological problems, social, cultural, and environmental influences that shape behaviour and attitudes towards and among the elderly.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology of Aging

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as a series of short videos totaling 2-3 hours/topic (4-6 hours/week) posted on Quercus. Students will have the opportunity for a synchronous online office hour on Wednesdays from 2-3pm via MS Teams to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Discussion boards will also be available to ask questions if students are unable to attend live office hours. Students will also have the option of attending a live feedback conference about their written assignments with the instructor or TA via MS Teams. Students are expected to collaborate with a small group of students to discuss important questions related to real-life applications of course material (provided by course instructor). This collaboration could be live or use Quercus discussion boards. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to access an online textbook.

cmCourseInfo.description:
An in-depth examination of theories and research in intergroup relations;
focuses on stereotyping, prejudice, discrimination, and stigma.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intergroup Relations

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online modules asynchronously, including videos, quizzes, and other small lecture-related activities.
There will be two lecture modules per week (total of about 6 hours of lecture time per week).
Students will be able to attend the lectures synchronously on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 1-4pm if they wish to, however, these lectures will be posted and available for students to do on their own time in the modules.
Additionally, students will have the opportunity for synchronous virtual office hours with the course instructor on Tuesdays at 10am and Thursdays at 8pm to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content and assignments.
Students will also be able to arrange virtual meetings outside of these time with the course instructor and teaching assistants. Please note that all times are given in Eastern Time (i.e., Toronto time).
Students need Word, PDF, and Internet access for this course. We will be using various features in Quercus (including Bb Collaborate) as well as other free sites, such as Piktochart.

cmCourseInfo.description: The effect of sex-role expectations on how men and women behave and perceive the world: theories of sex-role development, physiological and cultural determinants of sex differences, power relationships between men and women.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sex Roles and Behaviour

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals with psychological issues in the law, with particular reference to criminal law. It focuses mainly on research that has been done on pretrial publicity, eyewitness testimony, rules of evidence, and other factors that might affect jury decisions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology and the Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/twice a week asynchronously. The midterm will be synchronous during class time. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar/office hours 2hrs/week (Monday and Thursday 3-4pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: Illustrates major methodologies within social psychology, such as attitude measurement, observation of small groups, and experiments. Course capacity is limited to 15 students and priority is given to PSY Specialists and Research Specialists during the first enrolment period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology Laboratory

cmCourseInfo.description: A review of the field of positive psychology, which is the study of happiness and fulfillment. Topics include personal growth, meaning, hedonic and eudaimonic approaches to well-being, gratitude, awe, flow states, mindfulness and meditation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Positive Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online, hybrid course. 
The course will consist of 4-6 hours of online lectures and videos that can be viewed asynchronously each week. 
Students can choose to listen to the lecture portion synchronously on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 12 noon - 2 pm if they desire. 
As part of this course students will also participate in small group discussions during some weeks. These will take place synchronously but will be scheduled based on group members' time zones and availability. 
Students will also can attend optional synchronous office hours on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 2pm - 3pm to ask questions or discuss course material. 
Students need the ability to use Canvas and Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) including its audio (and ideally video) functions.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines various theories of how personality functioning may become impaired and corresponding psychotherapeutic interventions. Emphasis on empirical assessment of personality dysfunction and therapy effectiveness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories of Psychopathology and Psychotherapy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online hybrid course. Lectures will be posted as video recordings (2-3 hours) twice per week asynchronously (Tuesdays and Thursdays 5-8pm). Tutorial sessions will also be offered on BB Collaborate at several points during the semester (during class time - i.e., either on Tuesday or Thursday from 5-8pm) for review and clarification of lecture content. Tutorial sessions will be recorded and posted to Quercus, along with all other course materials. Virtual office hours sessions will be offered via BB Collaborate by request. Some assessments in the course will be timed and completed on Quercus during class time (Midterm assessment: Tuesday, July 23 at 5pm; Final assessment: Thursday, August 13 at 5pm).

cmCourseInfo.description: Current theories and data on human memory: processes involved in encoding, storage, and retrieval.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Memory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos (broken up into shorter chunks) twice per week, asynchronously.
To help students keep up with and learn the material each week, there will be a mini-tasks (e.g., participate in a discussion board, submit a question for the webinar, complete a mini-quiz).
Students will also have the option to attend a synchronous online webinar session 1-4hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content (Monday and Wednesday 6-7/8pm, depending on demand). This session will be recorded and posted for students who are unable to attend.
I will be available for office hours by appointment.
All readings including the textbook will be made available on Quercus.
Students will need access to a Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) to attend the synchronous sessions.
In general, students will need access to a computer, reliable internet, and a quiet space. I understand that this can be a challenge in this unprecedented time, I encourage students to contact me immediately and directly if they are facing these challenges.

cmCourseInfo.description: The functional relevance of neurotransmitters, with particular emphasis on their role in mediating behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurochemical Basis of Behaviour

These seminars vary from year to year in terms of the number given, the topics, and the restrictions on enrolment. Students must get prior consent from the instructor of the graduate seminar they are interested in taking and submit this consent in writing to the department at which time you will be enrolled for undergraduate credit. Consult the Undergraduate Administrator for more details.

notes.content:

Permission must be given first by the instructor, Dr. Li Shu (shu@mie.utoronto.ca), and enrolment is done through the department by contacting undergrad@psych.utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive laboratory or applied research project under the supervision of a Department of Psychology faculty member. Project must be academically demanding and uniquely suitable for the individual student. Additional information and applications are available at the department and on its website. This course is open to all Psychology program students.

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals, especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development, maintenance, disruption or dissolution of personal relationships, as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
My plan is to do lectures live Mondays and Wednesdays at 1:00 EDT, but to record them and make them available to be viewed at any time.
If for some reason the live lectures turn out to be problematic, I will revert to simply recording lectures and posting them. However, ideally, I would to be able to do lectures with real time feedback and questions.
I will also host a weekly office hour. My plan is to hold that on a weeknight at 6:00 pm. However, I would appreciate feedback on the practicality of that time for your world region and can adjust it accordingly.
Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.
Office hours will be held using Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals, especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development, maintenance, disruption or dissolution of personal relationships, as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online hybrid course. Lectures will be given as video recordings (2–3 hours) twice per week asynchronously. Virtual office hours sessions (1 hour) will be offered twice per week via BB Collaborate (TBA). Some assessments in the course will be timed and completed on Quercus on specific dates.

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course discusses visual attention; attentional selection for object recognition, feature integration, and action; attention in action-relevant space; movements of attention; eye-hand coordination, eye and limb movements; action-specific perception and effort-based models of perception; ecological perception and the perception of affordances.
cmCourseInfo.title: Attention and Performance

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online synchronous course.
Three-hour online lectures will be given twice weekly—Tuesdays and Thursdays 6PM to 9PM.
Students will need access to Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a capstone lecture course surveying research on how the mind arises from the brain. The first objective of the course is to understand how processes in human brains (ranging from the firing of a single neuron to the dynamics of billions) support cognitive abilities (such as recognizing a face, remembering a birthday from childhood, understanding the words in a spoken lecture, or planning a route home from class). The second objective of the course is to understand the methods of contemporary cognitive neuroscience research, to enable students to read primary literature and to understand ongoing debates.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cognitive Neuroscience

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course discusses the role of brain and body in the expression and experience of emotion in humans considered through the experimental, physiological, theoretical, and clinical literatures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Physiology and Psychology of Emotion

sections.subTitle: Radical Religions: Globalized Fundamentalisms and Reforms

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to topics in the study of Religion. Topics will vary by semester and year. Check the department website for upcoming topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introducing Religion

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as asynchronous online weekly videos. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week (Monday and Wednesday 11:00-12:00) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and course content. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) on quercus as well as the ability to view lecture slides (PPT).

cmCourseInfo.description: Religious violence and nonviolence as they emerge in the tension between strict adherence to tradition and individual actions of charismatic figures. The place of violence and nonviolence in selected faith traditions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religious Violence and Nonviolence

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as asynchronous online weekly videos. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) on quercus as well as the ability to view lecture slides (PPT).

cmCourseInfo.description: Course explores issues at the intersection of religion and science which may include such topics as evolution and the assessment of its religious significance by different traditions, conceptions of God held by scientists (theism, pantheism, panentheism), ethical issues raised by scientific or technological developments ( cloning or embryonic stem cell research), philosophical analysis of religious and scientific discourses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and Science

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 4 hrs synchronous online webinar class/week (Tuesday and Thursday 6-8 pm). Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) and Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: The role of film as a mediator of thought and experience concerning religious worldviews. The ways in which movies relate to humanity's quest to understand itself and its place in the universe are considered in this regard, along with the challenge which modernity presents to this task. Of central concern is the capacity of film to address religious issues through visual symbolic forms.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and Film

cmCourseInfo.description: Student-initiated intensive research courses supervised by faculty members of the Department. The student must obtain both a Supervisor's agreement and the Department's approval in order to register. The maximum number of Independent Research courses one may take is two full-course equivalents. Deadline for submitting applications to Department, including Supervisor's approval, is the first week of classes of the session. A full-course may be compressed into a single session or spread through two sessions; a half-course may similarly be done in either one session or across two sessions. These courses are open to majors and specialists only. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to management and its subdisciplines. Themes include business in a Canadian context, the nature of corporations, corporate governance, organizational behavior, operations, and strategy. Enrolment limited to students entering the University with an expressed interest in studying at Rotman Commerce.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Management

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Primarily synchronous, but some asynchronous (guest speakers)
Please note that this course is restricted to year 1 students who have not yet been accepted in the Rotman Commerce Program.

cmCourseInfo.description: Basic introduction to financial reporting and analysis. Emphasis is on decision-making and interpretation of financial statements and how they can be used to plan a firm’s overall business activities through the use of real-world companies. Coverage includes the use of accounting information to prepare a basic set of financial statements. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Financial Accounting

cmCourseInfo.description: Foundations of financial reporting and analysis in Canada.  Financial accounting topics are covered at an intermediate level, including both conceptual and technical aspects. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting I

cmCourseInfo.description: Covers topics such as income statement and balance sheet topics with an emphasis on quality of earnings. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting II

cmCourseInfo.description: Covers the conceptual and analytical foundations of management accounting and the applications of cost accounting information. Costing and control concepts are analyzed to equip students with tools for establishing costing systems, making business decisions, and evaluating management performance. Materials are designed to help students understand strategic cost management principles. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Management Accounting I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Rotman Commerce: RSM219H1; Employment Relations or Human Resource Management: MGT201H1

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical ideas and practical applications concerning the behaviour of individuals and groups in organizations. We explore relevant topics for management: motivation, personality, perception, decision-making, groups, and negotiation. A fee of $10 will be charged to your student account for a simulation handbook. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Organizational Behaviour

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Hybrid, primarily asynchronous with some synchronous activity

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the management of business processes that convert inputs (labor, material, equipment) into outputs (goods and services) for internal and external markets. Topics include aggregate planning, inventory processes, supply chain management and service operations management. Presents modern quantitative and computing tools necessary for in-depth operational design and analysis. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Operations Management

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the management of business processes that convert inputs (labor, material, equipment) into outputs (goods and services) for internal and external markets. cmCourseInfo.description: Topics and Issues in Management. Content in any given year will depend on the instructor. Consult the Rotman Commerce Portal for course description and prerequisites. cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Management

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Please note this is an online course to be offered from May through August 2020.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course emphasises the fundamentals of the Canadian tax system.  Included are topics, such as, residence of corporations and individuals, effective tax rates for corporations and individuals, business income, integration, capital gains and losses, to name a few.    A key objective of this course is to assist students in learning to read, interpret and apply provisions of the Income Tax Act to practical problems and cases. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Income Taxation I

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to capital market theory explaining how financial securities are priced. Topics covered include the time and risk value of money, the use of discounted cash flow techniques, efficient set theory, asset pricing and market efficiency. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Capital Market Theory

cmCourseInfo.description: Application and development of the ideas in RSM332H1 to corporate finance problems such as determining the weighted average cost of capital, project evaluation, corporate financing decisions, working capital management and initial public offerings. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Corporate Finance

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces core ideas, concepts and models in the area of Strategic Management. Addresses the following questions: Why does firm performance vary across industries, and across firms within a given industry? What types of competitive strategies can managers pursue? When are different types of strategies more or less likely to be successful?  Enrolment is restricted to 3rd or 4th year Rotman Commerce students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Strategic Management

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to give the student an understanding of more complex issues of Canadian income tax law and tax planning. Included are topics, such as, computation of taxes, corporate reorganizations, business acquisitions and divestitures, partnerships, joint ventures and trusts, to name a few. The two course sequence (RSM324H1 and RSM424H1) has been designed to provide coverage of the tax content required by the professional accounting bodies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Income Taxation II

cmCourseInfo.description: Describes important fixed income securities and markets. The course emphasizes traditional bond and term structure concepts crucial to understand the securities traded in these markets. Students are required to work in the Rotman Financial Research & Trading Lab to solve the assigned problems using real time data. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fixed Income Securities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Rotman Commerce: RSM332H1; Actuarial Science: ACT349H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Hybrid; Lectures will by synchronous, but there will also be videos posted covering the material as well.

cmCourseInfo.description: Applying fundamental finance ideas developed in RSM332H1 and RSM333H1 to real-life problems. The course will focus on business valuation and financial decisions in practical situations, on the assumption that students are already familiar with basic concepts from previous finance courses. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Corporate Finance
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Rotman Commerce: RSM333H1; Actuarial Science: ACT349H1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers the analysis of derivative instruments such as forwards, futures, swaps and options. By the end of the course, students will have good knowledge of how these contracts work, how they are used and how they are priced. A fee of $35 will be charged to your student account for software purchase. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Futures and Options Markets

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: Focuses on developing an understanding of the fundamentals of doing business in an international environment. Based on the application of management theory (trade theory, modes of entry, foreign direct investment, theory of the multinational) to the strategic management problems of organizing business in the international arena. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Contact Rotman Commerce for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Strategy

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary examination of sexuality across cultures and periods. How are sexualities represented? How are they suppressed or celebrated? How and why are they labeled as straight, gay, lesbian, bisexual, queer, or perverse? How do sexualities change with race/ethnicity, class, gender, and geographies?
cmCourseInfo.title: Histories of Sexuality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous using Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate.

courses.name: Special Topics in Sexual Diversity Studies A

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics vary from year to year depending on instructor. This seminar is intended to expose students in the Sexual Diversity Studies program to topics that may not be covered by permanent university courses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Sexual Diversity Studies A
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SDS255H1/SDS256H1/UNI255H1/UNI256H1 or permission of the instructor

cmCourseInfo.description: A research essay under the supervision of a faculty member with knowledge of sexual diversity, the proposal and supervisor subject to the approval of the SDS Program Director. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Essay in Sexual Diversity

cmCourseInfo.description: A research essay under the supervision of a faculty member with knowledge of sexual diversity, the proposal and supervisor subject to the approval of the SDS Program Director. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Essay in Sexual Diversity

cmCourseInfo.description: A major research essay prepared over the course of two academic terms (one year); under the supervision of a faculty member with knowledge of sexual diversity; the proposal and supervisor subject to the approval of the SDS Program Director. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Honours Essay in Sexual Diversity

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Please contact Valley Weadick in UC251, Monday to Friday, 9:00am to 4:30pm for further information or email sexual.diversity@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Basic features of the grammar. Acquisition of essential vocabulary for practical conversation and for comprehension. Development of reading and writing skills. (May not be taken by students who, in the judgment of the Department, qualify for entry into SLA210H1 or SLA220Y1).
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Russian I

cmCourseInfo.description: Basic features of the grammar. Acquisition of essential vocabulary for practical conversation and for comprehension. Development of reading and writing skills. (May not be taken by students who, in the judgment of the Department, qualify for entry into SLA210H1 or SLA220Y1).
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Russian II

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Course Added: April 17, 2020.
Online hybrid- see timetable instructions.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the Russian novelistic tradition at the height of its creative power. We examine the Russian novel’s universal appeal and influence, and its impact on modern art and thought. Authors may include (depending on instructor) Gogol, Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Belyi, Nabokov, Pasternak, Solzhenitsyn. Taught and read in English.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Russian Novel

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. It will be taught through a combination of synchronous and non-synchronous delivery. The non-synchronous component involves recorded lectures (4 hours per week, made available Mon and Wed). There will be 2 hours of live discussion per week (Tue and Thur, 1 to 2pm). Students need access to a webcam and ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to acquaint students with the essential notions of media studies, and to promote a conscious utilization of contemporary media. Starting with the preliminary definitions of media, mass, and communications, the student is invited to consider critically the cultural constructs created by modern media, from print to photography, filming, TV, computer and Internet.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media in Culture and Society

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-2hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: An historical introduction to the evolution of printing processes since Gutenberg. Attention is given to topics such as the mechanization of printing, the industrialization of the book chain since the nineteenth century, typography and publishing. Visits to rare book collections are an integral part of the course. Note: this course is not intended as a guide to self-publishing nor as a workshop on book making.
cmCourseInfo.title: Book History and Print Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. Each online “live” session (Monday and Wednesday 10am to 1pm) is normally divided into three parts: (a) a lecture, to introduce the key concepts, mostly from weekly readings; (b) a case study-based presentation and discussion, including questions and clarifications about lecture; and (c) an active learning activity, including online tutorials and learning exercises. Part (a) lecture will be recorded and available to students following each session. Lecture slides and other learning materials, such as weekly readings, case studies, and digital handouts will be posted on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Zoom for all online sessions and Quercus for readings, assignments, and tests.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the history of reading in western culture, from ancient Greece to the twenty-first century. Attention is given to topics such as the causes and effects of different modes of reading (silent or vocalized, intensive or extensive, educational or escapist), book clubs, censorship, and the ways in which readers have influenced cultural production.
cmCourseInfo.title: Readers and Readerships

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. A pair of two-hour lectures will be made available each week. Students will also have the opportunity for synchronous online discussion of the lectures and course readings on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3-4pm. All students will need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and to broadcast audio and video to their fellow classmates.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Course Added: April 8, 2020.
Students will require access to the internet to stream lectures and submit coursework.
Online Asynchronous – See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: A deeper examination of key cases in the development of media, such as the invention of movable type, the mechanization of the printing press, standardization of call number systems (Dewey, LC, etc.), the advent of radio, television and internet. Topics vary from year to year, according to the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media Revolutions

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-2hr online videos and/or slides/week asynchronously. Students will have opportunity for a few optional synchronous online webinar meetings (Wednesdays, 2-4pm) with Professor to ask questions and receive clarification about course content and assignments. Students need access to Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Social media tools and platforms are deeply embedded in our contemporary lives. But what consequences do they have for how we think, how we feel, how we socialize, how we understand ourselves, and how our networked society and culture functions? Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions with reference to their everyday experiences and current examples.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Technology and Networks
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment priority for students enrolled in a Book and Media Studies program

courses.name: Introduction to Sociology I: Sociological Perspectives

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will challenge your views on a wide range of issues that affect us all. It will also excite your interest in a unique sociological way of understanding your world. We will analyze the globalization of culture, emerging patterns of class, race, and gender inequality in Canada and internationally, criminal and deviant behaviour, and so on. You will learn to understand these and other pressing social issues by analyzing the way the social world is organized. These topics are further taken up in the sequel to this course, SOC150: Introduction to Sociology II: Sociological Inquiries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sociology I: Sociological Perspectives
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC101Y1, SOC102H1, SOC103H1, SOCA01H3, SOCA02H3; SOC100H5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Quercus, UofT 0365 MS Teams or Skype for Business

courses.name: Introduction to Sociology II: Sociological Inquiries

cmCourseInfo.description: In the sequel to SOC100H1: Introduction to Sociology I: Sociological Perspectives, this course will explore in more depth the topic of social inequality and the contemporary debates that animate sociology. We may like to think of ourselves as perfectly free but powerful social forces open up some opportunities and close off others, constraining our freedom and helping to make us what we are. By examining the operation of these social forces, sociology can help us know ourselves. The course is also about skills-building, skills useful not only for success at U of T, but beyond the walls of the university.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sociology II: Sociological Inquiries
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC101Y, (SOC102H + SOC103H), SOC200H1, SOC200Y1, SOCB05H3, SOC221H5, SOC200Y5

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the history, nature, and role of sociological theory, through an examination of the works of key classical theorists such as Karl Marx, Max Weber, Emile Durkheim, Georg Simmel, and others. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Sociological Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
BB Collaborate, PowerPoint, MP4 and Word

courses.name: Introduction to Quantitative Methods in Sociology

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction in quantitative social science research from descriptive statistics to hypothesis testing using various strategies for the analysis of bivariate relationships. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods in Sociology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC200Y5, SOC222H5, ECO220Y1, ECO227Y1, GGR270H1, PSY201H1, STA220H1, STA248H1, POL222H1, POL232H1, POL242Y1, POL322H1, STA288H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
BB Collaborate (through Quercus) and SPSS (free download); MS Word

courses.name: Introduction to Qualitative Methods in Sociology

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the methods and issues of qualitative research, the theories, methods for data collection and analysis, and the personal and ethical issues relating to qualitative research. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Qualitative Methods in Sociology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Quercus, BB Collaborate, PowerPoint and Skype

cmCourseInfo.description: This course reviews theories of urban genesis and urban form; the interrelationship of urbanization, industrialization and modernization, issues in urban living (housing, transportation, urban-renewal, poverty, unemployment, etc.); urban social networks (ethnic and cultural heterogeneity, neighbourhood, community and other voluntary associations).
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Sociology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines questions related to sexuality, with a special focus on the social construction of sexual identity, practice, community and desire. To do so, we proceed self consciously with a critical analysis of the modern study of sexuality, and the ways in which sexual science, as a kind of social practice, has affected the construction and regulation of sexual orientation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sexuality and Modernity
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC395H1 (taken in Winter 2015, Winter 2016),  SOC387H1 (taken in Fall 2016, Fall 2017), SOC386H1 (taken in Winter 2018)

cmCourseInfo.description: The course explores the concepts of race and ethnicity and major theories to understand race and ethnic relations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociology of Race and Ethnicity

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an overview of the study of crime and deviance. We critically examine how scholars have gone about studying crime and deviance (the methods they use and the statistics they employ) as well as the major sociological explanations for crime and deviance. We also consider the empirical evidence as it relates to the validity of these explanations and some of the policy fallout from different theoretical approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociology of Crime & Deviance

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Quercus, BB Collaborate (within Quercus) and Zoom, PowerPoint, Word & mp3 files

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines diverse family patterns, to show the economic, political and cultural factors that influence families. A brief social history of family paves the way for an examination of the various family patterns common in Canada today. Special attention is paid to the gender relations at the heart of family.
cmCourseInfo.title: Family Patterns

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is concerned with the causes and consequences of economic inequality. More specifically, it explores how achieved and ascribed characteristics are related to social class and related economic outcomes. Although some of the material will be comparative and pertain to modern Democracies generally, emphasis will be on Canadian society.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Inequality in Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
PP, Bb Collaborate+ (in Quercus) & MS Teams

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines (1) the social causes of illness and disease, (2) the experience of illness, and social processes that shape both of these issues, including medicalization. It focuses on population health, the relation between agency and structure, and macro-micro connections. Professional health care is discussed to the extent that it provides context for analyses of illness patterns and experiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociology of Health and Illness

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals with population aging, cohort effects, inter-generational relations, historical variation in effects of social environment on aging, how health and family relationships vary with age, and social policies related to aging. The whole life course is considered, but the emphasis on adulthood and old age.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociology of Aging

cmCourseInfo.description: A selective introduction to major contemporary thinkers and approaches whose ideas have achieved wide influence, as well as an on-going inquiry into the nature and role of sociological analysis. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Sociological Theory

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with the opportunity to develop an understanding of the logic of multivariate analysis by applying various strategies for the analysis of complex multivariate data. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Quantitative Methods in Sociology

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth examination of key methods of qualitative research, and an opportunity to design and conduct qualitative research that draws from key debates, methodologies, and methods in the field. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Qualitative Methods in Sociology

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity to explore new topics in sociology. Topics vary from year to year based on the instructor. Consult the Departmental website: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/new-topics-in-sociology/
cmCourseInfo.title: New Topics in Sociology

courses.name: HIV and AIDS: Social Policies and Programs

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores and discusses specific theories of action. Applies theories to various factors associated with AIDS/HIV. Examines political, scientific, health, social, economic, and cultural environments. This course forces students to examine the hidden theoretical assumptions surrounding AIDS/HIV.
cmCourseInfo.title: HIV and AIDS: Social Policies and Programs

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Quercus, BB Collaborate (within Quercus) and Zoom, PowerPoint, Word & mp3 files

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how society has gone about controlling specific types of deviants (e.g., gang members, sex and drug offenders) and acts of deviance (e.g., organized crime, the deviance of social control agents). In examining these individuals and acts, attention is also directed to why they are defined as deviant and sanctioned, and why some types of deviance are less likely to be detected and sanctioned than others. Finally, consideration is also given to a range of sanctions that have been used to control deviance and the empirical evidence on their effectiveness. This is a program-only course and is restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Control
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC201H1, SOC202H1, SOC204H1 & 1.0 FCE from SOC251H1/SOC252H1/SOC254H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Quercus, PowerPoint and Bb Collaborate +

cmCourseInfo.description: This course analyzes the interplay between new communication technologies and society. It will consider how technological developments affect social systems, and conversely, how social systems affect the nature and use of technology. Much of the course will be devoted to studying the impact of computerization and the advent of the information highway. This is a program-only course and is restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Technology and Society
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC201H1, SOC202H1, SOC204H1 & 1.0 FCE from SOC251H1/SOC252H1/SOC254H1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the social processes that characterize stratification and social inequality across the globe, by looking at whether global inequality is growing, shrinking or stagnant and the impact of globalization on global inequality, with particular emphasis on examining disparities over time in education, income/wealth and health. This is a program-only course and is restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Inequality

Consult the Departmental website: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/new-topics-in-sociology/. cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC201H1, SOC202H1, SOC204H1 plus two of the following (1.0 FCE): SOC251H1, SOC252H1, SOC254H1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the sociological study of collective action. Students will explore how movements in a variety of historical and global contexts endeavor to produce social change. In this process, we will examine political and cultural opportunities and obstacles, organizational dynamics, resources, collective action frames, strategies and tactics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Movements

courses.name: Sociology of Mental Health and Mental Disorders

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the link between social inequality and emotional inequality, focusing on differences in mental health across social groups and the role of stress and coping resources in explaining group differences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociology of Mental Health and Mental Disorders

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the dynamics of gender in daily life – in sexuality and intimate relations, in parenting and families, and in paid work and workplace organizations, as well as in popular culture. It examines the social construction of gender in individuals and in social organizations, in order to understand gender inequality.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender Relations

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the labour market and employment situation of immigrants emphasizing recent Canadian experience in comparative context. Topics include immigrant human capital, declining immigrant earnings, immigrant skill-underutilization, impact of the knowledge economy, racial discrimination, labour market structure and unionization, immigrant entrepreneurship and experiences of the Canadian-born second generation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Immigration and Employment
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: SOC317Y1 or SOC336H1 or SOC366H1 or SOC383H1

cmCourseInfo.description: How location in socioeconomic, ethnic, gender, and generational groups shapes individual cultural repertories; how culture affects individual positions in stratification hierarchies; and the role of culture in group boundaries and struggles.
cmCourseInfo.title: Culture and Inequality

cmCourseInfo.description: Independent Research courses allow students to pursue a specific topic of interest. These courses are offered at the 300-level, as full or half courses. Students work independently with a professor in the Department who acts as research supervisor. There are no formal class meetings, lectures, or readings other than what is agreed to with the supervisor. Professors accept supervisory responsibility at their discretion. They are not required to serve as research supervisors. It is recommended that students approach a professor working in the same sub-discipline of sociology. Often students become interested in a topic through a SOC course and approach the instructor of that course for supervision; however, this is not required. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. For further details, please visit our website at: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/independent-research-course/
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students must have completed 10.0 courses towards their degree, plus a SOC course at the 300+ level to be eligible for 300-level Independent Research.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the sociological implications associated with the growing dominance of psychiatry over designating and managing the margins of ‘normality’ and ‘deviance.’ It covers the evolution of the DSM and rise of deinstitutionalization, the importance of stigma and symbolic interactionist understandings of psychiatric diagnoses, and the methods of social control used to mitigate risk and reduce social deviance within the psychiatric and criminal justice systems. Emphasis will be placed on understanding the social implications of mental health labels. Restricted to 4th-year sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medicalization of Deviance

cmCourseInfo.description: This fourth year course will provide an advanced treatment of selected topics in political Sociology. Specific topics to be covered are the relationship between political systems and cleavage voting, the relationship between social class and attitudes and voting, the post-materialist thesis, social capital and civic participation, gender politics, the various varieties, causes and effects of welfare states, and social movements. The course will have both a Canadian and international focus. Restricted to 4th-year sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Studies in Political Sociology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers real world observation and abundant examples that speak to the strengths and limitations of particular theory, data, and methods for studying urban problems. Students undertake a supervised research project that involves identifying, observing and reflecting on real phenomena in the urban environment. Restricted to 4th-year sociology specialists and majors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Urban Sociology
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: SOC312H1 or SOC364H1 or SOC384H1 or SOC205H1

Timetable Instructions
This is an online hybrid course. Lectures and tutorials will meet synchronously (Mondays and Wednesdays 10-11AM; Tuesdays and Thursdays 10-11:30AM); students will also have to complete assignments asynchronously (estimate about 8 hours/week): readings, videos, exercises, writing, etc. Students need a webcam and audio recording capabilities (e.g. computer with a microphone) to access Bb Collaborate and to undertake oral and listening assessments.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intermediate Spanish for non-native speakers. Intensive grammar review of the structures of Spanish integrated with an introduction to reading authentic Spanish material, with practice designed to build vocabulary and to improve oral and written expression.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course in statistical concepts and methods, emphasizing exploratory data analysis for univariate and bivariate data, sampling and experimental designs, basic probability models, estimation and tests of hypothesis in one-sample and comparative two-sample studies. A statistical computing package is used but no prior computing experience is assumed. Note: STA220H1does not count as a distribution requirement course.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Practice of Statistics I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Grade 12 Mathematics and one University course in the physical, social, or life sciences

Timetable Instructions

Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Probability, Statistics and Data Analysis I

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to probability using simulation and mathematical frameworks, with emphasis on the probability needed for more advanced study in statistical practice. Topics covered include probability spaces, random variables, discrete and continuous probability distributions, probability mass, density, and distribution functions, expectation and variance, independence, conditional probability, the law of large numbers, the central limit theorem, sampling distributions. Computer simulation will be taught and used extensively for calculations and to guide the theoretical development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Probability, Statistics and Data Analysis I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: STA247H1, STA255H1, STA257H1, ECO227Y1, STAB52H3, STA256H5, ECO227Y5

courses.name: Probability, Statistics and Data Analysis II

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to statistical inference and practice. Statistical models and parameters, estimators of parameters and their statistical properties, methods of estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, likelihood function, the linear model. Use of statistical computation for data analysis and simulation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Probability, Statistics and Data Analysis II
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: STA248H1, STA255H1, STA261H1, ECO227Y1, STAB57H3, STA258H5, STA260H5, ECO227Y5

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be held online at the scheduled times. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions during class, tutorial or in online office hours. More information about the set-up of this course and the available resources and supports will be available in the course syllabus. Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: A mathematically rigorous introduction to probability, with applications chosen to introduce concepts of statistical inference. Probability and expectation, discrete and continuous random variables and vectors, distribution and density functions, the law of large numbers. The binomial, geometric, Poisson, and normal distributions. The Central Limit Theorem. (Note: STA257H1 does not count as a distribution requirement course).
cmCourseInfo.title: Probability and Statistics I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ECO227Y1, STA247H1, MAT377H1, STAB52H3, STA256H5, ECO227Y5

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note

Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be held online at the scheduled times. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions during class, tutorial or in online office hours. More information about the set-up of this course and the available resources and supports will be available in the course syllabus. Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: A rigourous introduction to the theory of statistical inference and to statistical practice. Statistical models, parameters, and samples. Estimators for parameters, sampling distributions for estimators, and the properties of consistency, bias, and variance. The likelihood function and the maximum likelihood estimator. Hypothesis tests and confidence regions. Examples illustrating statistical theory and its limitations. Introduction to the use of a computer environment for statistical analysis. (Note: STA261H1 does not count as a distribution requirement course).
cmCourseInfo.title: Probability and Statistics II

cmCourseInfo.description: Design of surveys, sources of bias, randomized response surveys. Techniques of sampling; stratification, clustering, unequal probability selection. Sampling inference, estimates of population mean and variances, ratio estimation. Observational data; correlation vs. causation, missing data, sources of bias.
cmCourseInfo.title: Surveys, Sampling and Observational Data

cmCourseInfo.description: Experiments vs observational studies, experimental units. Designs with one source of variation. Complete randomized designs and randomized block designs. Factorial designs. Inferences for contrasts and means. Model assumptions. Crossed and nested treatment factors, random effects models. Analysis of variance and covariance. Sample size calculations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Design and Analysis of Experiments

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of probability from a non-measure theoretic point of view. Random variables/vectors; independence, conditional expectation/probability and consequences. Various types of convergence leading to proofs of the major theorems in basic probability. An introduction to simple stochastic processes such as Poisson and branching processes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Probability

courses.name: Selected Topics in Ethics, Society, and Law

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines a set of selected topics in ethics, society, and law. The topics will be based on the research interests of an individual instructor. Both the topics and the instructor may change with each offering of the course, and the course is not expected to be offered every year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Selected Topics in Ethics, Society, and Law
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment in ASMAJ1618. A student must be in third or fourth year.

cmCourseInfo.description: This interdisciplinary, foundational course provides an introduction to contemporary Canadian society. The course includes the study of geography, politics, literature and culture through a historical framework of the twentieth century. It also emphasizes particular themes including indigenous issues, Quebec nationalism, gender/women's issues and immigration/multiculturalism. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Canada

cmCourseInfo.description: Digital Humanities (DH) studies human culture -- art, literature, history, geography, religion -- using computational tools and methodologies, and at the same time studies digital technologies and communities through humanist lenses, as complex cultural objects shaped by wider social and political concerns and the ways we construct knowledge and meaning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Digital Humanities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4 FCEs at the 100 level, at least 1 FCE of which must be in Humanities

sections.name: LEC9901
sections.subTitle: COVID-19 Pandemic: A Historical and Digital Humanities Perspective

cmCourseInfo.description: This course serves as a capstone for the Digital Humanities Minor program. It includes opportunities for students to conduct original research. The topics for this course will vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Digital Humanities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WDW235H1 and WDW236H1, plus at least 1.0 additional FCE in the Digital Humanities Minor program.

cmCourseInfo.title: Gender in Popular Culture

cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topic in Women and Gender Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The synchronous component will be given on Monday and Wednesday, 10 -12pm. The asynchronous component is a student-driven learning experience. Students are required to have access to computers/laptops and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary study of gendered violence in both historical and contemporary contexts including topics such as textual and visual representations; legal and theoretical analyses; structural violence; war and militarization; sexual violence; and resistance and community mobilization.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender and Violence

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Lectures will be given as online videos, 2-3 hrs each week. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar classes 1-2 hrs each week (Wednesday 6-8pm) for discussions, including questions about course materials and assignments. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate. Classes that fall on the first week of class (Mon. July 6 and Wed. July 8) and the class following the Civic holiday (Wed. Aug 5) may have a mixture of asynchronous and (non-mandatory) synchronous components.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course communicates the growing field of "girl studies" and provides a critical exploration of the historical, social, psychological and political definitions attached to girlhood.  We will move toward a feminist understanding of how definitions of girl-child shape individual experience, historical narratives, cultural representations, political agendas and futures.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Politics of Girlhood

notes.name: Course Note

Students will be required to participate in discussions on an online message board at least once/week. Students need access to Blackboard Collaborate.

courses.name: Translating Sexuality: Queer Migration, Queer Diasporas

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how notions of sexuality travel as people move within and beyond national borders. It investigates how queer and trans migrants pursue different versions of belonging, solidarity, survival, and hope. Participants will study transnational archives (which may include popular culture, new media, film, literature, and performance) as they trace globalization's effects on racialized, queer, and trans communities. Major topics may include: queer of color critique; queer settler colonialism; transnational and global south sexualities; imperialism and militarism; neoliberalism and homonationalism; humanitarianism and sexual rights; queer and trans social movements; postcolonial intimacies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Translating Sexuality: Queer Migration, Queer Diasporas
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1, one full course at the 300+ level in WGS, and one half course in WGS
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS434H1 (Topics: Trans/national Sexuality), offered in Fall 2016 and Fall 2017
